abstract.para: Before you start a cluster resource, make sure it is set up correctly. For example, if you use an Apache server as a cluster resource, set up the Apache server first. Complete the Apache configuration before starting the respective resource in your cluster.

note.title: Do not touch services managed by the cluster
note.para: When managing a resource via the &ha; software, the resource must not be started or stopped otherwise (outside the cluster, for example manually or on boot or reboot). The &ha; software is responsible for all service start or stop actions.
However, if you want to check if the service is configured properly, start it manually, but make sure that it is stopped again before the &ha; software takes over.
For interventions in resources that are currently managed by the cluster, set the resource to maintenance mode first.

topic.para: You can start a cluster resource using either &hawk; or &crmsh;.

When creating a resource with &hawk;, you can set its initial state with the target-role meta attribute. If you set its value to stopped, the resource does not start automatically after being created.
To start a new cluster resource with &crmsh;, you need the respective identifier.

step.para: Log in as &rootuser; and start the crm interactive shell:
Start the resource with start and press the key to show all known resources:
From the left navigation bar, select Monitoring Status. The list of Resources also shows the Status.
Select the resource to start. In its Operations column, click the Start icon. To continue, confirm the message that appears.
When the resource has started, &hawk; changes the resource's Status to green and shows on which node it is running.
